utterances: Now, mathematically, you just gave us a sense of what Senator Clinton would need to win the nomination.
Let's talk about Michigan and Florida again.
Is there a chance that these votes will be added to the tally?
I mean, the Clinton spokespeople have been really saying she's won the popular vote.
Is that accurate?
She has won the popular vote only if you include some states, and you exclude some others states.
And it probably won't surprise you to hear that the states you would include would be ones she has won, and the states you would exclude would be ones Obama has won.
That's how they can get to that construct of saying that they have won more popular votes.
And they are very close in popular votes, no matter how you counted.
This has been a remarkably close contest between these two historic candidates, first woman to get this close to the nomination, first African-American.
And this has been a very close contest throughout.

But in order to get Hillary Clinton out in the lead on popular votes, and she did close the gap further last night because she had a bigger win in Kentucky than Obama had in Oregon, to get her over the top you have to include Michigan and not give him credit for any votes in Michigan at all.
His name was not on the ballot, but the people who wanted to vote for him voted for uncommitted.
You'd have to give him no credit for those at all.
And then down in Florida, you'd have to count all the votes fully, even though that's probably not what' s going to eventually happen.
And then in addition to that, you'd have to exclude those caucus states that reported only delegate totals and not the raw vote totals of the actual people who were there voting.
Had they been counted, of course, that would add greatly to Obama's numbers.
Do we have any sense of how the Democratic National Committee and Chairman Dean are going to play their cards?

I mean, is this going to be a situation where you anticipate they're going to start saying what's going to happen in Florida and Michigan when there's a Rules Committee meeting at the end of the month?
There is, indeed, on May 31st.
That's Saturday, a meeting of the Rules and Bylaws Committee, and they are going to, one would think, decide the issue of what's going to happen with Michigan and Florida.

Now, the Michigan situation might be close to resolution because some of the leaders of the Democratic Party there, the same people who insisted on moving their primary into January in cooperation with the Republican Party there, those same people have devised a plan which would give Hillary Clinton about ten more delegates, 69 to Barack Obama's 59.
So she would pick up a net of 10 delegates out of that Michigan compromise.
That's not enough to make much difference.
So the Clinton people are holding out for a better deal than that, and the Obama people are holding off to see what exactly it takes to get a compromise.
But that's what's been proposed by the Michigan Democratic Party itself, and I think that that compromise would be acceptable to the national committee.
Florida is a little tougher.
Florida's a lot more delegates, yet.
We're talking about 185 delegates out of Florida.
That's a huge cash.
And at this point, that's really the big kahuna.
So any compromise out of Florida is going to have to be very carefully vetted by the committee.
And one that I've looked at would give her 55 percent of the vote, give Obama 45 percent of the vote, and that would pick up almost 20 delegates for her.
There is almost no sector in Greece that's gone untouched by that country's roiling financial crisis.
One of the hardest hit is the country's hospitals, where budgets have been slashed by more than half since 2007.
The facilities lack basic supplies, like surgical gloves, something the European Center for Disease Control and Prevention says will contribute to high infection rates.
And nearly all doctors have seen their pay cut, delayed or frozen.
Joanne Kakissis visited a state hospital in the northern Greek city of Serres, where the staff is overworked, underpaid and demoralized.
(SOUNDBITE OF COUGHING)
DR. CHARALAMBOS VELIOTIS: (foreign language spoken)
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: (foreign language spoken)
Pediatrician Charalambos Veliotis is examining a young brother and sister in matching track suits.
They've been coughing for 10 days now.
(foreign language spoken)
We only have five pediatricians in the entire region, he says.
The region is called Serres, and it's in the northern province of Macedonia, on the border with Bulgaria.
More than 200,000 people who live here.
Dr. Veliotis says he sees the effects of the country's 26 percent unemployment rate on his young patients.
(Through Translator) We're seeing children with severe malnutrition.
We're seeing children who have fainted in school from hunger.
Depression is common because their parents are unemployed.
(foreign language spoken)
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #2: (foreign language spoken)
(SOUNDBITE OF BABY CRYING)
His next patient is a three-day-old infant girl with a cleft lip.
He gives the baby's parents tiny syringes and shows them how to relieve her nasal congestion with saline.
(Through Translator) We ration supplies, medicine, everything.
Sometimes, we pay out of our own pockets to buy them.
Dr.
Veliotis has been practicing for eight years, but he makes just under $2,000 per month, after a 30 percent pay cut.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHATTER)
The Regional Hospital of Serres has 100 doctors and 80 residents.
The main entrance is draped with a hand-painted banner denouncing the budget cuts.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHATTER)
Neurologist Vangelis Papamichalis checks out a patient's brain scan.
He makes about $1,600 a month and often works nearly 100 hours a week.
Because the state hasn't paid bills to pharmacies, his epilepsy patients often wait days for their medication.
DR.
VANGELIS PAPAMICHALIS: Through Translator) In medical school, we were taught to give our patients the most modern care.
But in reality, we're working under the same conditions as 50 years ago.
Last year, he tried to save a man in the emergency room who had suffered a massive stroke.
(Through Translator) Because we don't have a stroke unit, we couldn't relieve his thrombosis.
He died.
I was so upset because if I had the resources to do what I needed here, this man could have made it.
Dr.
Papamichalis says he wants to stay in Greece and fight for health care reform.
But his colleague Dimitris Kokkinidis, who's a hematologist, says he's lost hope.
DR. DIMITRIS KOKKINIDIS: (foreign language spoken)
Many days, we run out of vials for blood samples or we don't have reagents needed to test the blood, he says.
It's just tragic.
His salary has been cut in half.
He now makes about $1,200 a month.
His wife, Despina Rizopoulou, a family doctor at a private clinic, hasn't been paid for 11 months.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHATTER)
Dr.
Rizopoulou works at a Euromedica Red Cross clinic in the nearby city of Thessaloniki, where the couple lives with their three young children.
Euromedica is owed millions by the Greek state and by the new government of Libya, whose war victims were treated here last year.
DR.
DESPINA RIZOPOULOU: All this floor, third floor, was filled with Libyans, with no other patients were here.
And they didn't receive the money that was agreed with the Libyans.
She's not sure she will ever get paid, so she and her husband are now looking for jobs in England and Switzerland.
I can't stand anymore this insecurity.
Everything here is collapsing: the health system, the educational system.
We just can't imagine our children growing up in an environment like that.
For NPR News, I'm Joanna Kakissis in Thessaloniki.
Alex, when Americans go out to vote, there will be at least a million poll workers greeting them.
These workers get up at dawn to set up election booths and pass out ballots until well after dark.
One of them is 79-year-old Patricia Speicher.
She's been a poll worker in Ohio for most of her life.
Patricia Speicher joined me earlier.
She told me about her first election in 1948.
The precinct committee person was a friend of my dad's and we were in a Democratic precinct.
He was having trouble finding someone.
He says, If you were older, I'd take you.
And I says, I'm 21.
And so that's how I started.
You've been doing this for most of your life.
What motivates you?
I feel like that is a civic duty and something that should be done.
And I like to meet people.
It's your own neighborhood so you're talking to the people in your neighborhood that you don't normally get to see at all.
Well, Tuesday's going to be a long day for you.
What will you be doing and how long do you expect to be working?
We have to be there at 6:00 in the morning.
Polls open at 6:30 and we have to get everything organized for it.
And the polls close in the evening at 7:30.
Then we do a little bit of tabulation.
There's not much anymore since we have so much computerization.
We don't have to count all the ballots.
So we're out of there by 8:00.
It always rises to the fore when you have a bad economy.
This is a standard response, particularly from politicians in an election year.
Lim doubts this latest outbreak of protectionism will last, but it could well continue through November.
